lens.lens_summary: An investor host with multiple units reveals how System 1/System 2 dynamics govern every phase of the host journey: trust forms through automatic impressions (System 1) but converts only when process details satisfy deliberate evaluation (System 2), and every moment of cognitive overload or ambiguity triggers the law of least effort toward abandonment or default refusal.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Andreas discovered Split Lease because Bryant found his Craigslist listing and reached out to him (andreas-call.txt, 0:50: 'Craigslist is where I found the Washington Heights apartment'). The host did NOT discover Split Lease; Split Lease discovered the host. This inverts the typical discovery model. Kahneman's System 1 framework reveals why this matters: when a host encounters an unsolicited outreach message, System 1 immediately performs a threat/opportunity assessment. The outreach must pass the automatic 'is this a scam or an opportunity?' filter before System 2 engages to read the details. Andreas's willingness to engage (he texted Bryant back, referenced at 0:15: 'I texted you about the Washington Heights') indicates his System 1 classified the outreach as a plausible opportunity rather than spam. The critical System 1 signals that likely enabled this: Bryant contacted him about a SPECIFIC property (his listing), not a generic pitch. Kahneman's concept of associative coherence (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, 'The Associative Machine') explains why specificity matters: mentioning the host's own property activates a coherent network of associations (my listing, my income, my vacancy problem) that frames the outreach as relevant rather than random.

user_state.emotional_state: Neutral-to-curious. Andreas shows no skepticism or anxiety in the call, suggesting he has already passed the initial suspicion barrier during the discovery phase. His System 1 has classified Bryant as 'legitimate contact about my property' rather than 'stranger to be wary of.' This is evidenced by his casual, business-like tone from the first seconds of the call (0:09: 'How can I help you?') and his volunteering of detailed property information without hesitation (1:03-1:10: two units, floor numbers, availability).
user_state.knowledge_level: Andreas knows nothing about Split Lease as a company at discovery. He posted a Craigslist listing and received a text from Bryant. He does not yet understand the periodic tenancy model, the roommate matching concept, or the payment guarantee structure. His mental model at discovery is likely 'someone responding to my rental listing' rather than 'a platform with a new rental paradigm.'
user_state.commitment_level: Low but non-zero. Andreas has already taken one action: he texted Bryant back (0:15). This micro-commitment indicates his System 1 impression was positive enough to warrant a response. Per Kahneman's law of least effort (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt: 'people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action'), responding to a text is a low-effort action, meaning the barrier to this first commitment was appropriately low.
user_state.data_available: At discovery, we have the host's Craigslist listing data: property location (Washington Heights), number of units, floor details, amenities shown in photos (unfurnished, laundry, microwave). We do not yet have the host's name, email, credit preferences, or financial requirements.

reasons: System 1 threat detection: unsolicited outreach triggers default suspicion in low-trust environments. If the initial message does not reference the specific property or sound professional, System 1 classifies it as spam and the host never responds.

Law of least effort: if the outreach requires the host to do anything complex (visit a website, fill out a form, call back), the effort prediction discourages engagement. Andreas responded to a TEXT, the lowest-effort channel.

Associative incoherence: if the outreach message uses unfamiliar terminology ('periodic tenancy,' 'split lease') without anchoring to familiar concepts, System 1 cannot categorize it and defaults to avoidance.
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas's Craigslist origin (0:50) combined with Kahneman's observation that 'System 1 continuously generates suggestions for System 2: impressions, intuitions, intentions, and feelings. If endorsed by System 2, impressions and intuitions turn into beliefs' (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt). The discovery channel (text about a specific property) succeeded because it aligned with System 1 expectations: someone interested in my listing.

key_quotes.quote: Craigslist is where I found the Washington Heights apartment.
key_quotes.relevance: Confirms the discovery channel. The host was found on Craigslist, not the other way around. This means the platform's discovery phase for hosts is outbound, not inbound.

key_quotes.quote: I texted you about the Washington Heights.
key_quotes.relevance: Shows that the first contact was via text message. The host's System 1 evaluated the text as worth responding to, indicating the message passed the automatic legitimacy check.

key_quotes.quote: Ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity in your brain... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
key_quotes.relevance: Explains why referencing the host's specific property in the discovery outreach works: it activates a coherent network of associations (my property, my vacancy, my income need) that frames the outreach as relevant.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: The Andreas call IS the evaluation phase. The entire 6-minute call is Andreas evaluating whether Split Lease is worth working with. Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework reveals the dual-track evaluation happening simultaneously: System 1 is continuously assessing Bryant's tone, competence, and trustworthiness (automatic, effortless), while System 2 is deliberately processing specific details: furnishing options, deposit requirements, broker's fees, credit checks, and payment guarantees. The call structure reveals that evaluation is not a single decision but a cascade of micro-evaluations, each of which must pass before the host continues. Andreas asks about furnishing (1:29), hears the answer, then moves to deposits (3:02), then broker's fee (3:16), then payment process (3:28-3:51), and finally logistics (5:27-5:54). Each answer satisfies one System 2 concern and primes readiness for the next. Kahneman's concept of 'cognitive ease' is operating: Bryant's clear, structured answers create a sense of fluency that System 1 interprets as trustworthiness.

user_state.emotional_state: Engaged and increasingly confident. Andreas moves from asking basic questions (1:29: 'Are they furnished?') to collaborative problem-solving (5:12: 'if they just go there to sleep, just a bed, things for the kitchen'). This shift from questioning to advising indicates System 2 has endorsed System 1's positive impression. By 5:44 ('You can just email me at any time'), Andreas is actively facilitating the next steps, signaling emotional buy-in.
user_state.knowledge_level: Evolving rapidly through the call. By the end, Andreas understands: (1) Split Lease matches roommates (1:58-2:19), (2) there is a customer rental agreement defining responsibilities (2:43-2:54), (3) Split Lease runs credit checks and vets tenants (3:28-3:42), (4) payments are pre-authorized and guaranteed (3:42-3:51), (5) furnishing is the tenants' responsibility with third-party options (4:36-4:54). He does NOT yet understand the periodic tenancy model (nights-of-week vs. full-time). Bryant pitched this as a standard roommate placement, not a split-schedule arrangement.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium-high by end of call. Andreas agrees to showings (1:18: 'I can show them both'), offers his email (5:27), and expresses interest in a second property (5:54: 'I'd love to see that other place as well'). These are concrete commitment actions, not just verbal interest. Per Kahneman, these micro-commitments build consistency pressure: having agreed to show two units, System 2 would need a strong reason to reverse course.
user_state.data_available: By the end of evaluation, we have: host name (Andreas), two property locations (Washington Heights, one block apart), floor details (5th floor walk-up, 2nd floor), amenities (unfurnished, laundry in building, microwave), financial requirements (first month + deposit + one month broker fee = 3 months upfront), credit requirements (excellent credit), showing availability (weekends), and communication preference (email and text).

reasons: Cognitive overload during the call: if Bryant had presented too many concepts at once (periodic tenancy, three lease models, pricing tiers, agreement details), System 2 would have been overwhelmed. Kahneman warns: 'if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action' (law of least effort). Overwhelm during evaluation leads to 'I will think about it' which means abandonment.

Ego depletion: Andreas is managing a building project ('I'm actually building a bar in my house,' 0:15) while evaluating this opportunity. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that 'after exerting self-control in one task, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.' A cognitively depleted host defaults to the easier path: saying no.

Unresolved gap between call and platform: the evaluation happens entirely via phone call with Bryant. If the host is then directed to a website that looks different, feels different, or requires re-learning everything Bryant explained, the transition creates a System 1 disruption (associative incoherence between 'smooth phone call' and 'confusing website').
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas's practical, rapid-fire questioning style (furnishing at 1:29, deposit at 3:02, broker fee at 3:16, payment at 3:28) shows System 2 actively evaluating. Bryant's structured responses keep cognitive load manageable. Kahneman: 'We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps' (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, Attention and Effort). Bryant instinctively does this by addressing one concern at a time.

key_quotes.quote: We collect payment from the guests and guarantee that to you as the landlord. We've run a credit check and vetted both Ariel and Amber. We pre-authorize the charges to them at the signing of the agreement. That's basically how we're able to guarantee payments to you.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the key System 2 evaluation moment. Bryant provides a PROCESS explanation (how guarantee works), not just a CLAIM (we guarantee payment). Kahneman's work on associative coherence explains why process > claim: a coherent causal chain (credit check -> pre-authorization -> guarantee) activates a reinforcing network of trust associations.

key_quotes.quote: Excellent credit on every single tenant.
key_quotes.relevance: Andreas's credit requirement reveals his System 2 evaluation criteria. He is not evaluating on emotion or relationship; he is evaluating on verifiable standards. The platform must surface these verifiable signals to satisfy investor-type hosts.

key_quotes.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... little strain. You make many small decisions as you drive your car, absorb some information as you read the newspaper, and conduct routine exchanges of pleasantries with a spouse or a colleague, all with little effort and no strain.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant conducts the evaluation at System 2's 'natural speed' -- conversational, not pressured. This prevents the cognitive strain that would trigger the law of least effort toward disengagement.

key_quotes.quote: If you're telling me that they just go there to sleep, I think just a bed, things for the kitchen.
key_quotes.relevance: Andreas shifts from evaluating TO advising. This is the moment System 2 endorses System 1's positive impression. He is now co-creating the solution, not interrogating it. This marks the transition from evaluation to implicit onboarding.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: The Andreas call reveals a critical gap: there is no structured onboarding. The call ends with an exchange of emails (5:27-5:44) and a plan to schedule showings, but no mention of signing up on the platform, creating an account, or entering the digital system. The onboarding is entirely human-mediated (Bryant will 'send over some information' and 'reach out shortly after the call,' 6:03-6:11). Kahneman's framework reveals why this matters: the phone call created a state of cognitive ease and associative coherence (smooth conversation, clear answers, growing trust). Transitioning to a digital platform introduces what Kahneman calls a 'conflict between an automatic reaction and an intention to control it' (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, Conflict section). The host's System 1 has formed the association 'Split Lease = Bryant = trustworthy conversation.' The platform must inherit this trust, or System 1 will flag the unfamiliar digital interface as a disruption, triggering renewed skepticism.

user_state.emotional_state: Post-call warmth. Andreas has just had a positive, efficient conversation. He feels like he is dealing with a competent person (Bryant) who has real tenants (Ariel and Amber) ready to go. This emotional state is fragile: it was built by the phone call and will decay over time (Kahneman's concept of 'what you see is all there is' -- the positive impression is based on limited information and will be questioned when the host encounters the platform).
user_state.knowledge_level: Andreas understands the human side (Bryant matches roommates, collects payment, guarantees rent) but not the platform side (account creation, listing wizard, proposal management). He does not know he will need to create an account, configure a listing through 6 steps, set pricing, define rules, or manage proposals digitally. This knowledge gap between 'what Bryant explained' and 'what the platform requires' is the onboarding challenge.
user_state.commitment_level: Moderate. Andreas agreed to showings and email exchange, but has not committed to the platform. There is a significant step-up in commitment from 'let Bryant show the apartment' to 'create an account and manage my listing digitally.' Per Kahneman's law of least effort, if the digital onboarding feels significantly harder than the phone conversation, Andreas will gravitate back to the easier path: just dealing with Bryant directly.
user_state.data_available: Post-call we have everything from the evaluation phase plus the host's email (requested at 5:27). We do not yet have an account, a listing, or any platform-native data.

reasons: Trust transfer failure: System 1 trust was built with Bryant (a person), not Split Lease (a platform). The platform must explicitly bridge this gap or the host's first encounter with the website triggers a new System 1 evaluation, potentially negative.

Cognitive effort cliff: the phone call was conversational (low cognitive load). The listing wizard is a 6-step form (high cognitive load). Kahneman: 'the most effortful forms of slow thinking are those that require you to think fast' (Attention and Effort). If onboarding feels like a timed test rather than a guided conversation, the host will abandon.

Ego depletion from evaluation: the host just spent 6 minutes in System 2 deliberation (evaluating terms, doing mental math on 3 months upfront). Kahneman: 'an effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around' (The Busy and Depleted System 2). The host arrives at onboarding with a depleted System 2.

Time gap: the call ends with 'I'll be reaching out shortly' (6:03). Any delay between the call and the onboarding email allows the warm impression to cool, and new doubts (System 2 second-guessing) to emerge.
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas's call ends with a handoff to email (5:27-5:44, 6:03-6:11) but no mention of the platform. The journey map (split-lease-journey-map.md) shows onboarding requires: Homepage -> Auth Modal -> Host Dashboard -> Create New Listing modal. That is 4 navigational steps before any listing work begins, each one an opportunity for System 1 to flag confusion or System 2 to decide it is not worth the effort.

key_quotes.quote: Could I get your email, just send over some information... You can just email me at any time.
key_quotes.relevance: The onboarding handoff is email-based, not platform-based. This reveals that the human agent (Bryant) is the onboarding mechanism, not the digital product. The platform must either replicate Bryant's role or integrate seamlessly with the human handoff.

key_quotes.quote: I'll be reaching out to you shortly after the call. If you could send over your email.
key_quotes.relevance: The time-sensitivity is acknowledged ('shortly') but no specific commitment is made. Kahneman's research on parole judges shows that delay leads to default denial. Any gap between the call and the next touchpoint risks the host defaulting to inaction.

key_quotes.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
key_quotes.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
key_quotes.relevance: After a 6-minute evaluation call, the host's System 2 is partially depleted. Onboarding that demands further System 2 effort (account creation, form filling, decision making) will face resistance. Onboarding should be designed for a depleted user.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Andreas has two units with clearly defined attributes: floor level, furnishing status, laundry, microwave, and pricing requirements. The call reveals that an investor host like Andreas thinks of listings in terms of COMPARABLE UNITS ('I have two units... both of them are available, I can show them both,' 1:03-1:10) rather than unique spaces. The journey map shows a 6-step wizard (Space Snapshot, Features, Lease Styles, Pricing, Rules, Photos). Kahneman's framework predicts two key risks in this phase: (1) Decision fatigue from the 6-step sequence. Kahneman: 'making a series of choices that involve conflict' is a known depletor of self-control (The Busy and Depleted System 2). Each wizard step requires choices, and the cumulative effect is ego depletion. (2) The law of least effort will drive hosts toward defaults. Kahneman: 'tired and hungry judges tend to fall back on the easier default position' (the parole judge study). In listing creation, this means hosts will accept default pricing, default rules, and default features rather than customizing, which may result in suboptimal listings.

user_state.emotional_state: Task-oriented but potentially frustrated. Andreas is a practical host (5:12: 'just a bed, things for the kitchen'). He wants to get the listing done, not explore options. If the wizard feels exploratory rather than directive, his System 2 will resist. Kahneman's concept of flow (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Lazy Controller) is relevant: if the wizard creates 'effortless concentration,' the host will complete it. If it creates strain, the host will abandon.
user_state.knowledge_level: Andreas knows his properties well (floor numbers, amenities, pricing) but does not know the platform's vocabulary or categories. The journey map shows Step 3 asks for 'Lease Styles' (Nights-of-the-week), a concept Andreas was never introduced to in the call. Bryant pitched the arrangement as 'roommates who need a space during the week for work' (2:19), not as a 'nights-of-the-week lease style.' This vocabulary mismatch between the human pitch and the platform's categories creates a System 1 confusion moment.
user_state.commitment_level: High for the first listing (he has tenants waiting), but the second listing depends on how painless the first one is. Kahneman's priming research is relevant: the experience of creating Listing 1 primes the host's expectations for Listing 2. A painful first experience primes avoidance; a smooth first experience primes willingness.
user_state.data_available: From the call: property type (apartments), location (Washington Heights), floors (5th and 2nd), amenities (unfurnished, laundry in building, microwave), and the host's financial requirements (first month + deposit + broker fee). The listing wizard will need to collect: space type, bedrooms, kitchen type, parking, bathrooms, address, features, lease style, pricing, rules, and photos.

reasons: Six-step wizard is cognitively expensive. Kahneman: 'effort is required to maintain simultaneously in memory several ideas that require separate actions' (Attention and Effort). The host must hold their mental model of the property while navigating unfamiliar UI concepts (lease styles, feature templates).

Vocabulary mismatch between call and platform. Bryant said 'roommates who need a space during the week.' The platform says 'Nights-of-the-week lease style.' System 1 flags this incongruence, and System 2 must expend effort to reconcile it.

Multi-unit hosts face multiplication of effort. Andreas has two units. If creating one listing is effortful, creating two feels like double the work. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts the host may create one listing and postpone the second indefinitely.

Photo upload friction. The journey map shows photos are the final step. By Step 6, ego depletion from 5 prior decision-heavy steps makes photo uploading (which requires leaving the platform to find files) feel disproportionately burdensome.
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas describes his units efficiently in about 30 seconds of conversation (1:03-1:18: unit count, floors, availability, showing schedule). The 6-step wizard will take significantly longer than 30 seconds. Per Kahneman: 'As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes' (law of least effort, Attention and Effort). First-time listing creation has maximum cognitive cost because no skill has been built.

key_quotes.quote: I have two units. One of them is on the fifth floor walk up. And then the other one is a second floor walk up.
key_quotes.relevance: Andreas conveys listing information in 7 seconds of natural speech. The listing wizard must allow similarly efficient input or it will feel like a step backward from the phone conversation.

key_quotes.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
key_quotes.quote: Tired and hungry judges tend to fall back on the easier default position of denying requests for parole.
key_quotes.relevance: By Step 4-6 of the listing wizard, the host is ego-depleted. They will accept defaults rather than optimize. Smart defaults become critical: the platform's defaults must be good enough that accepting them produces a quality listing.

key_quotes.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
key_quotes.relevance: The wizard's multi-step structure aligns with this principle, but only if each step is truly easy. If individual steps contain sub-decisions (choose from 20 features, select lease style you have never heard of), the steps themselves become overloading.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: Andreas operates with a clear, simple pricing model: first month + deposit + one month broker's fee = 3 months upfront (3:02-3:16). He does not think in terms of nightly rates, 4-week rent calculations, or periodic tenancy pricing. The journey map shows the Listing Detail Page displays 'Nightly rate' and '4-Week Rent total,' and the Proposal Summary shows 'Price per night,' 'Total price for the reservation,' and 'Price for the first 4 weeks.' This multi-format pricing creates exactly the kind of cognitive load Kahneman warns about. System 2 must perform mental arithmetic to reconcile nightly rates with monthly expectations. Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Lazy System 2) demonstrates that over 50% of highly educated people fail at simple math when an intuitive but wrong answer is available. If the platform presents pricing in an unfamiliar format, the host's System 1 will generate an intuitive (possibly wrong) interpretation that System 2 may be too lazy to correct.

user_state.emotional_state: Pricing is where financial anxiety peaks. Andreas's 3-month upfront requirement (3:02-3:16) is a risk-management behavior: he wants cash in hand before granting access. The platform's pricing model (nightly rates, 4-week cycles) may feel less secure than traditional monthly rent because the numbers are smaller and the time horizons shorter. Kahneman's loss aversion principle (not explicitly in Part 1, but implied through the risk-avoidance patterns) suggests the host will weight potential losses from unfamiliar pricing more heavily than potential gains.
user_state.knowledge_level: Andreas understands traditional rental pricing (monthly rent, deposit, broker's fee) but not periodic tenancy pricing (nightly rates multiplied across specific days). The gap between his mental model ('$X per month rent') and the platform's model ('$Y per night x selected days x weeks') requires System 2 translation that adds cognitive load at a moment when clarity is essential.
user_state.commitment_level: Pricing is a commitment gate. If the numbers make sense, commitment increases sharply. If the numbers are confusing or seem lower than expected, commitment drops. Andreas's practical mindset (evidenced throughout the call) suggests he will engage deeply with pricing IF the math is transparent.
user_state.data_available: From the call: deposit required (first month), broker's fee (one month), total upfront (3 months). The platform's Step 4 (Pricing) presents 'default values already populated' per the journey map. The question is whether those defaults align with what Andreas expects or require reconciliation.

reasons: Format mismatch: the host thinks monthly, the platform shows nightly. Converting between formats requires System 2 computation. Kahneman: 'You could not compute the product of 17 x 24 while making a left turn into dense traffic' (Attention and Effort). Mental math during an already effortful process compounds cognitive strain.

Default acceptance risk: the journey map says Step 4 has 'default values already populated' and the host 'reviews and accepts the defaults.' Kahneman's parole judge research predicts that a depleted host (after Steps 1-3) will accept defaults without evaluation. If defaults are wrong, the listing launches with incorrect pricing.

Anchoring: Kahneman's anchoring research (not deeply covered in Part 1, but implicit) suggests that whatever number the host sees first becomes the anchor. If the default nightly rate seems too low relative to the host's monthly expectation, it triggers System 1 alarm ('this does not seem right') that may cause abandonment.
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas's rapid-fire pricing questions (deposit at 3:02, broker at 3:16, total at 3:16: 'Three months. Okay. Got it.') show a host who processes financial information quickly but linearly. He needs clear, sequential numbers, not multi-dimensional pricing tables.

key_quotes.quote: That's something that I do require. I require first month... broker's fee? The amount one month. Okay. Three months. Okay. Got it.
key_quotes.relevance: Andreas processes pricing as a simple sum: first + deposit + broker = 3 months. The platform should present pricing with similar clarity: one calculation, one total, one commitment.

key_quotes.quote: More than 50% of students at Harvard, MIT, and Princeton gave the intuitive -- incorrect -- answer [to the bat-and-ball problem].
key_quotes.relevance: If highly educated people fail at simple math under cognitive ease, hosts facing unfamiliar pricing formats during a depleting wizard will fare worse. Pricing must be pre-calculated and unambiguous.

key_quotes.quote: The law of least effort applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
key_quotes.relevance: The 'least demanding course of action' at the pricing step is accepting defaults. This makes default pricing quality a critical design concern.

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: The Andreas call does not directly address proposal management, but it powerfully foreshadows the host's expectations for this phase. Bryant explains that 'Ariel and Amber both came to us individually and we matched them as roommates' (1:58) and that the rental agreement 'defines the relationship between Ariel and Amber' (2:43). Andreas's mental model is that Bryant handles the matching, the agreement, and the terms. When proposals arrive on the platform, the host's expectation (primed by the call) is that the work has already been done. Kahneman's priming research (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Marvels of Priming) is directly relevant: the phone call primes the host's expectations for the platform experience. If Bryant said 'we handle everything,' the host expects the platform to reflect that -- presenting proposals as nearly-done-deals rather than negotiations requiring active management. The journey map shows proposal management requires: notification discovery, proposal review, term modification, counter-offer confirmation. Each step demands System 2 attention that the primed host may not expect to invest.

user_state.emotional_state: Expectant but potentially surprised. Andreas expects Bryant to handle logistics (implied by 6:03: 'I'll be reaching out to you shortly after the call'). Receiving a digital proposal notification instead of a personal call may feel impersonal, triggering System 1's threat detection: 'this is not what I expected.' Kahneman: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains' (Plot Synopsis). A platform notification violates the 'Bryant handles this personally' model.
user_state.knowledge_level: Andreas does not know proposals exist as a platform concept. He knows Bryant will 'send over' information (5:27) and that there is a 'customer rental agreement' (2:43). The platform's proposal workflow (submit, counter, accept) was never mentioned in the call. The host will encounter this workflow cold.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditional. Andreas is committed to the TENANTS (Ariel and Amber, whom he knows by name) but not to the PROCESS. If the proposal management process feels like bureaucracy rather than facilitation, his commitment drops. Per Kahneman, 'activities that impose high demands on System 2 require self-control, and the exertion of self-control is depleting and unpleasant' (The Busy and Depleted System 2).
user_state.data_available: At proposal stage, the platform has: the host's listing, the guest's desired terms (duration, days, pricing), and the pre-existing relationship context from the call (Bryant matched these specific people). This context should be surfaced to reduce the cognitive load of proposal evaluation.

reasons: Expectation violation: the host was primed by the phone call to expect human-mediated logistics. Platform-mediated proposal management is an unannounced shift in interaction mode.

Notification discovery: the journey map shows proposals are discovered through a notification icon. If the host does not check the platform regularly (likely, since Andreas prefers email and text), the proposal may sit unreviewed. Kahneman: 'we can be blind to the obvious, and we are also blind to our blindness' (the gorilla experiment). A host focused on other tasks will miss platform notifications.

Counter-offer complexity: modifying proposal terms (duration, pricing) requires System 2 deliberation at a moment when the host may be checking the platform casually (System 2 in 'low-effort mode'). Kahneman: 'System 2 is normally in a comfortable low-effort mode' (Plot Synopsis). Asking for deliberate analysis during casual browsing creates friction.
dropout_risk.evidence: The journey map Phase 3 requires: Homepage -> Auth Modal -> Dashboard -> Notifications -> Proposal Detail -> Edit Terms -> Counter Confirmation. That is 7 navigational steps to counter a proposal. Andreas provided all his terms verbally in under 60 seconds during the call. The platform's 7-step counter process will feel disproportionately effortful relative to the call experience.

key_quotes.quote: Ariel and Amber both came to us individually and we matched them as roommates. They both live in Connecticut and need a space... they'd be using it just to sleep each night.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant presents the proposal as a pre-packaged deal: two vetted tenants, matched, with a clear use case. The platform's proposal management should maintain this sense of pre-packaged readiness rather than requiring the host to re-evaluate from scratch.

key_quotes.quote: Exposure to a word causes immediate and measurable changes in the ease with which many related words can be evoked... priming is not restricted to concepts and words. Your actions and your emotions can be primed by events of which you are not even aware.
key_quotes.relevance: The phone call primes the host's entire expectation framework for the platform. Every platform interaction is evaluated against the primed expectations. If the call promised ease and the platform delivers complexity, the negative surprise is amplified by the contrast.

key_quotes.quote: We have a customer rental agreement which sort of defines the relationship between Ariel and Amber... we define the cleaning responsibilities as well as storage and other things.
key_quotes.relevance: The agreement is presented as something Split Lease defines, not something the host negotiates. The proposal management UI must maintain this frame: the host is reviewing and approving, not creating from scratch.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address the active lease phase. The Andreas call ends before any lease is signed. However, two important signals emerge. First, Andreas's practical mindset (5:12: 'just a bed, things for the kitchen') suggests he will be a low-maintenance host during the active lease, focused on payment receipt rather than relationship management. Second, Kahneman's concept of the 'law of least effort' predicts that during the active lease, both host and guest will gravitate toward minimal interaction. The platform should support this by automating payment tracking, schedule management, and issue resolution rather than requiring active participation. The journey map describes 'Active Lease management with payment schedules and date change marketplace.' For an investor host like Andreas, the active lease phase is ideally invisible: payments arrive on time, tenants are quiet, and the host only engages when something requires attention (System 2 mobilized by surprise, not by routine).

user_state.emotional_state: This lens cannot directly evidence the active lease emotional state. Projected from the evaluation phase: Andreas will be satisfied as long as payments arrive reliably (3:28-3:51: the payment guarantee was his key evaluation criterion) and tenants maintain the property. Kahneman's 'comfortable low-effort mode' (Plot Synopsis) is the target emotional state: the host's System 2 should not need to engage during normal active lease operation.
user_state.knowledge_level: Unknown from this lens. The host will need to understand: payment schedules, date change requests, how to handle issues, and lease renewal. None of these were discussed in the call.
user_state.commitment_level: High once the lease is active (sunk cost, signed agreement, tenants in place). Dropout at this stage means breaking a legal agreement, which is high-friction. The risk shifts from dropout to dissatisfaction.
user_state.data_available: During active lease: payment history, tenant compliance, date change requests, maintenance requests. The platform should surface only exceptions (missed payments, schedule changes) rather than status updates (everything is fine).

reasons: Legal commitment reduces dropout to near-zero during the lease term.
The only dropout risk is non-renewal at lease end, which is a retention concern rather than an active lease concern.

Kahneman's framework suggests that if the active lease operates at 'System 2's natural speed' (low-effort monitoring), the host remains satisfied. Problems arise only when unexpected events demand System 2 mobilization (missed payment, damage report, schedule conflict).
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas's payment guarantee focus (3:28-3:51) suggests his primary active lease concern is financial reliability. If the guarantee holds, his System 2 has no reason to engage, and his System 1 impression remains positive.

key_quotes.quote: We pre-authorize the charges to them at the signing of the agreement. That's basically how we're able to guarantee payments to you.
key_quotes.relevance: The payment guarantee is the active lease's emotional foundation. If this works as promised, the active lease phase is effortless for the host. If it fails, every other aspect of the relationship is compromised.

key_quotes.quote: System 1 runs automatically and System 2 is normally in a comfortable low-effort mode, in which only a fraction of its capacity is engaged.
key_quotes.relevance: The target state for the active lease: System 1 handles routine (payment notifications, calendar updates) and System 2 is only called when something unexpected occurs.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address retention. The Andreas call is a first-contact conversation with no discussion of long-term relationship, renewal, or multi-lease engagement. However, Kahneman's priming and associative coherence concepts offer a powerful retention prediction: the host's entire future relationship with Split Lease is being PRIMED by these early interactions. Every positive micro-experience (smooth call, clear answers, reliable payment) builds an associative network where 'Split Lease' activates positive feelings, making renewal a System 1 default. Every negative experience (confusing platform, missed payment, poor communication) builds the opposite network, making non-renewal the System 1 default. Kahneman: 'ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity' (The Associative Machine). Retention is not decided at renewal time; it is built or eroded across every prior interaction.

user_state.emotional_state: This lens cannot directly evidence the retention-phase emotional state. Projected: if the active lease delivered on Bryant's promises (guaranteed payment, vetted tenants, smooth process), the host approaches renewal with positive System 1 associations. If promises were broken, System 1 associations are negative and System 2 must be convinced with new evidence.
user_state.knowledge_level: By retention, the host is experienced. They know the platform, the process, and the outcomes. Kahneman: 'As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes' (Attention and Effort). A returning host requires less cognitive effort than a new one, making the platform experience smoother -- if they return.
user_state.commitment_level: Depends entirely on prior experience. Andreas has two units (1:03). If the first unit's lease goes well, listing the second unit becomes almost automatic (System 1 default). If it goes poorly, System 1 flags the entire platform as a threat, and no amount of System 2 persuasion may overcome it. Kahneman: 'biases cannot always be avoided, because System 2 may have no clue to the error' (Illusions). A negative first impression can persist even when contradicted by evidence.
user_state.data_available: At retention: full lease history, payment records, tenant feedback, host satisfaction signals. The platform should use this data to make the renewal decision effortless (pre-populated renewal terms, proactive outreach before lease end).

reasons: Retention depends on the cumulative associative network built across all prior phases. A single severe negative experience (missed payment, property damage, poor platform experience) can dominate the network and prevent renewal.
Multi-unit hosts like Andreas are both high-value retention targets and high-risk: losing one unit's lease may cause them to withdraw both.

The law of least effort predicts that renewal must be EASIER than finding tenants through other channels (Craigslist, word of mouth). If the host's prior experience of the platform was effortful, the alternative channels look more attractive by comparison.
dropout_risk.evidence: Andreas found his current listing method (Craigslist) easy enough to use (0:50). For retention, Split Lease must be demonstrably easier and more reliable than Craigslist. Kahneman's framework predicts that the comparison is made by System 1 (gut feeling about effort and reliability) not System 2 (detailed analysis of pros and cons).

key_quotes.quote: Each element is connected, and each supports and strengthens the others... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
key_quotes.relevance: Retention is the cumulative result of associative coherence built across the entire journey. Every phase either reinforces or undermines the 'Split Lease = positive experience' network.

key_quotes.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes.
key_quotes.relevance: A returning host requires less cognitive effort. The platform should recognize returning hosts and reduce friction accordingly (pre-filled forms, remembered preferences, streamlined flows).

key_quotes.quote: I have two units.
key_quotes.relevance: Multi-unit hosts represent compounding retention value. If the first lease goes well, the second unit follows naturally. The platform should explicitly support multi-listing workflows to capture this value.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: System 1 trust forms instantly and determines whether System 2 ever engages. This pattern recurs at every phase transition: discovery (does the outreach look legitimate?), evaluation (does Bryant sound competent?), onboarding (does the platform look professional?), listing creation (does the wizard feel manageable?), pricing (do the numbers look right?), proposal management (does the notification feel expected?). At each gate, System 1 performs an automatic assessment that either permits System 2 engagement or triggers abandonment.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman, kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt: 'If endorsed by System 2, impressions and intuitions turn into beliefs, and impulses turn into voluntary actions' (Plot Synopsis). Andreas's call shows this cascade: System 1 approved the initial text (discovery), then System 1 approved Bryant's tone (evaluation), leading to System 2 engagement with details (deposit, fees, credit). Each phase depends on the prior phase's System 1 approval.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The law of least effort creates a progressive depletion gradient across the journey. Each phase consumes cognitive resources, leaving less for subsequent phases. Discovery (low effort: read a text) -> Evaluation (medium effort: 6-minute call with decisions) -> Onboarding (high effort: navigate new platform) -> Listing Creation (very high effort: 6-step wizard). By pricing (Step 4 of wizard), the host is maximally depleted and most likely to accept defaults or abandon.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman, kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt: 'an effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around' (The Busy and Depleted System 2). Also: 'tired and hungry judges tend to fall back on the easier default position of denying requests for parole' (same section). Andreas's call shows the progressive engagement: casual start (0:09-0:36), then increasingly specific questions (1:29-3:16), then collaborative advising (5:12), then fatigue signals (wrapping up at 5:44-6:11).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Priming from earlier phases sets expectations for later phases. The phone call with Bryant primes every subsequent platform interaction. Associative coherence demands that the platform experience feel consistent with the call experience. Any incoherence (different terminology, different tone, different complexity level) triggers System 2 re-evaluation and potential rejection.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman, kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Marvels of Priming: 'exposure to a word causes immediate and measurable changes in the ease with which many related words can be evoked... your actions and your emotions can be primed by events of which you are not even aware.' Andreas's call established primes: 'we guarantee payments' primes expectation of financial reliability, 'we've run a credit check' primes expectation of quality tenants, 'I can send that over to you' primes expectation of proactive communication. Every subsequent platform interaction is evaluated against these primes.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The host-as-advisor pattern: when a host shifts from asking questions to offering advice, they have psychologically committed. This transition indicates System 2 has endorsed System 1's positive impression, and the host now sees themselves as part of the solution rather than an evaluator of it. This pattern can be designed for at every phase by creating moments where the host contributes expertise rather than consuming information.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Andreas-call.txt, 5:12: 'If you're telling me that they just go there to sleep, I think just a bed, things for the kitchen.' Also 5:18: 'my both units come with a microwave.' Andreas shifts from questioning mode (1:29-3:16) to advising mode (5:12-5:27). This is a commitment escalation that happened naturally in conversation. The platform should engineer similar moments: asking the host for their recommendation, their expertise, their preference -- not just their data.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The human-to-digital handoff is the highest-risk transition in the entire journey. Every phase that involves moving from human interaction (Bryant's call) to digital interaction (the platform) introduces associative incoherence. The host built trust with a person; the platform must inherit that trust without a person present.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Andreas-call.txt ends with human-to-human promises: 'I'll be reaching out to you shortly after the call' (6:03), 'You can just email me at any time' (5:44). No mention of the platform. The journey map (split-lease-journey-map.md) shows the next steps are entirely digital: Homepage -> Auth Modal -> Dashboard -> Listing Wizard. Kahneman, kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, Conflict: 'Conflict between an automatic reaction and an intention to control it is common in our lives.' The automatic reaction (Bryant is my contact) conflicts with the new intention (use this platform I have never seen).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Investor hosts like Andreas process information through an efficiency lens: they want minimum input for maximum output. Every phase must demonstrate ROI of attention. Kahneman's concept of 'effort as cost' (law of least effort) means these hosts are constantly calculating: is the effort of this step worth the outcome? If any phase feels like overhead rather than value creation, the host disengages.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Andreas-call.txt behavioral observations: 'Practical mindset -- if they just go there to sleep, just a bed, things for the kitchen.' He optimizes for efficiency at every turn: two units described in 7 seconds (1:03-1:10), pricing requirements summarized in one exchange (3:02-3:16), furnishing solved with minimal items (5:12). Kahneman, kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt: 'In the economy of action, effort is a cost, and the acquisition of skill is driven by the balance of benefits and costs. Laziness is built deep into our nature' (Attention and Effort).

sources_consulted.extracted: Complete 6-minute transcript of investor host with 2 Washington Heights units. Key data points: Craigslist discovery channel, text-based first contact, two units (5th floor walk-up, 2nd floor), unfurnished with laundry and microwave, 3 months upfront (first + deposit + broker fee), credit requirement (excellent credit on every single tenant), weekend showings, email/text communication preference. Behavioral shift from questioner (1:29-3:16) to advisor (5:12-5:27) marks commitment escalation. Call ends with human handoff (email exchange, no platform mention).

Core concepts applied: (1) System 1 operates automatically, processes first impressions, determines whether System 2 engages; (2) System 2 handles deliberate evaluation but is lazy and avoids unnecessary effort; (3) Law of least effort: people gravitate to least demanding course of action; (4) Ego depletion: after exerting self-control, less willing to make effort on next task; (5) Priming: exposure to concepts changes subsequent behavior without awareness; (6) Associative coherence: ideas activate related ideas in self-reinforcing cascades; (7) The bat-and-ball problem: over 50% of elite students accept wrong intuitive answers; (8) Parole judges: depleted decision-makers default to denial; (9) Flow state: effortless concentration where self-control is not needed; (10) Cognitive blindness: intense focus on one task makes people blind to other stimuli.

4-phase journey: Host Creates Listing (Homepage -> Auth -> Dashboard -> 6-step Wizard -> Manage Listing), Guest Creates Proposal (Homepage -> Auth -> Listing Detail -> Proposal Summary), Host Counters Proposal (Homepage -> Auth -> Dashboard -> Notifications -> Proposal Detail -> Edit Terms), Guest Accepts Counter-Terms (Homepage -> Auth -> My Proposals -> Acceptance). Key patterns: repeated auth cycles, avatar dropdown navigation, notification-driven discovery, confirmation dialogs, price transparency at every decision point.
Element library is empty (0 elements, 0 runs). All 8 journey phases have zero coverage. This is the first run producing elements.

Design tokens: warm earth palette (bg #f6f4f0, accent green #2d5a3d), Instrument Serif / Outfit / IBM Plex Mono typography, 6-step spacing scale, border radius from 6px to 9999px, easing curves including spring bounce, shadow system from subtle to prominent.
